title: 107_hr1819
content: The "Free Trade Community Relief Act" designates NAFTA-impacted communities for tax incentives, including employment credits and increased expensing. The "Free Trade Community Relief Act" designates NAFTA-impacted communities based on nominations by local governments and states, with final designation by the Secretary of Commerce after consultation with relevant departments. The "Free Trade Community Relief Act" allows the Secretary of Commerce to designate up to 35 nominated areas as NAFTA-impacted communities based on job loss criteria. The areas with the highest ranking in specified criteria will be selected for designation. The Secretary of Commerce will prescribe regulations for nominating NAFTA-impacted communities based on specified criteria, including size and population characteristics. The Secretary of Commerce will only designate a nominated area as a NAFTA-impacted community if the nomination is submitted in the required manner and contains accurate information. For Indian reservations, the reservation governing body will be treated as the nominating entity. The designation of an area as a NAFTA-impacted community is in effect from the date of designation until December 31, 2008, or until revoked by the Secretary of Commerce. The Secretary determines that the effects of NAFTA on the area have improved, with a focus on job loss alleviation and new businesses being attracted. To be designated as a NAFTA-impacted community, the area must meet specific eligibility requirements, including being within the jurisdiction of local governments. The eligibility requirements for a nominated area to be designated as a NAFTA-impacted community include being within the jurisdiction of local governments, having a continuous boundary, excluding empowerment zones and renewal communities, and meeting specific unemployment rate criteria certified by the State and local governments. The eligibility requirements for a nominated area to be designated as a NAFTA-impacted community include having an unemployment rate at least 1 percentage point above the national rate, with specific worker certification criteria for rural and urban areas. The eligibility requirements for a nominated area to be designated as a NAFTA-impacted community include having an unemployment rate at least 1 percentage point above the national rate, with specific worker certification criteria for rural and urban areas. In a rural area, it means an area with a population of less than 10,000 or outside a metropolitan statistical area. In an urban area, at least 500 workers need to be certified. The term 'urban area' is defined as any area that is not rural. If an area is designated as both a NAFTA-impacted community and an enterprise community, both designations will be fully effective. Special rules similar to section 1393 apply for this subchapter. "SEC. 1400L. NAFTA-IMPACTED COMMUNITY EMPLOYMENT CREDIT." The NAFTA-impacted community employment credit is 8.5 percent of qualified wages paid to qualified employees. Qualified wages are those paid for services by an employee who is a qualified NAFTA-impacted community employee, with only the first $15,000 of wages per year taken into account. The qualified NAFTA-impacted community wages for a calendar year cannot exceed $15,000 and do not include wages used for the work opportunity credit. The $15,000 limit is reduced by wages used to determine the work opportunity credit. A qualified NAFTA-impacted community employee is defined as per this section. In this subsection, a qualified NAFTA-impacted community employee is defined as someone whose services are mostly performed within a NAFTA-impacted community for an employer, and their primary residence is within that community. Other rules similar to section 1396(d) apply, and for further definitions and special rules, section 1397 is referenced. Increase in expensing under section 179. The text discusses the increase in expensing under section 179 for NAFTA-impacted community businesses, allowing for a higher limitation and a reduced amount taken into account for qualified NAFTA-impacted property. Rules for recapture apply if the property ceases to be used in a NAFTA-impacted community. The term 'qualified NAFTA-impacted property' refers to section 179 property acquired between December 31, 1999, and January 1, 2007, that would qualify as zone property if references to NAFTA-impacted communities were substituted for empowerment zones. Rules from section 1397C apply to this property. The term 'NAFTA-impacted community business' is defined in section 1400N. The term 'NAFTA-impacted community business' is defined as any entity or proprietorship eligible for certain benefits under the code. This includes a new employment credit as part of the general business credit. The amendment prohibits the carryback of the section 1400L credit before January 1, 2000. Additionally, a denial of deduction for a portion of wages equal to the NAFTA-impacted community employment credit is implemented. The amendment includes changes to section 196 and section 381 related to the NAFTA-impacted community employment credit under section 1400L(a). Carrybacks of the credit are prohibited before January 1, 2000, and a denial of deduction for a portion of wages equal to the credit is implemented. The corporation must consider the necessary items for subchapter XI in relation to the distributor or transferor corporation, as prescribed by the Secretary. Clerical amendments are made to the table of subchapters for chapter 1. SEC. 3. Grants for job training assistance for NAFTA-impacted communities. The Secretary of Labor will provide grants to States with NAFTA-impacted communities for job training assistance. Grants will be used to fund short-term job training courses, entrepreneurism, and self-employment programs to promote economic self-sufficiency. The maximum grant amount for a State in a fiscal year is $1,000,000 multiplied by the number of impacted communities in the State. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this purpose. Authorized appropriations of $35,000,000 annually from 2002 to 2008 for job training assistance in NAFTA-impacted communities. Amounts remain available until expended.
